transcripts.text: I can't slow down, I can't hold back, though you know I wish I could.

New details now on the assault charge just filed against an LAPD officer caught on camera beating a man in Boyle Heights last month.  An L.A.  County's district attorney tells the NBC4I team this one was a clear call.

The last thing we saw was a cell phone video recording that captured the confrontation between two LAPD officers and a man outside the fence of a church in Boyle Heights.  The officer could be seen repeatedly punching the man in the head as the eyewitness recorded the encounter from across the street.  Initially, the LAPD said it considered this a minimal use of force, but after the video was seen, And after body-worn video from the officers was reviewed, the case was elevated.  Prosecutors began reviewing the evidence last week, and L.A.  County District Attorney Jackie Lacy tells us they filed the felony charge within days.
It did seem to be clear that the officer lost his temper, got mad at the arrestee, and really began to wail on him with his fists.  So it wasn't really what I would call a close call.

The officer who the I-Team was able to identify last month is Frank A. Hernandez.  He's been on the LAPD since the 1990s.  He was removed from patrol work after this video was made public.  He's been ordered to surrender in court later this week.  The I-Team also found some police and court records that showed Hernandez had previously been involved in three on-duty shootings.  All of them were deemed lawful by the DA's office.

Okay then, Officer Frank A. Hernandez of the LAPD was involved in three on-duty shootings where the district attorney found them justified.  Thank God there was a video recorder going on while he was beating the shit out of this citizen.  Now let's see what they sentence him to.
